0.02.text:
Everyone remembers Yuri Gagarin the
first man in space but before his famous

5.42.text:
flight there had been many more living
space pioneers but didn't really have

10.46.text:
any choice about being strapped into an
experimental rocket. The tidal wave of

15.95.text:
propaganda generated by Sputnik 1 had
been unpredictable but it had been

20.84.text:
especially positive for the Soviet
leader Nikita Khrushchev. He summoned

25.13.text:
Sergey Korolyov the boss of the Soviet
space program and told him to make sure

29.45.text:
that a second satellite was launched in
time to mark the anniversary of the

33.62.text:
October Revolution of November 7th 1917,
giving Korolyov of just over three weeks

39.95.text:
to complete the task. Despite the short
notice

43.79.text:
Korolyov didn't want to send up another
bleeping sphere.

47.03.text:
He'd been developing his own ideas for
some time and wanted to score another

51.17.text:
first by putting the first living
creature

53.99.text:
aside from microbes into orbit and on
October 12th eight days after Sputnik 1

60.20.text:
the decision was made to send a dog.
Soviet scientist Boris Chertok later told

66.17.text:
how in the rush to design and build
Sputnik 2 all the rules that had been

70.76.text:
carefully drawn up violent missile
development team were abandoned in favor

75.20.text:
of a "gambler's enthusiasm" he wrote "The
second simple satellite was produced

80.96.text:
without any preliminary design or plan
the draftsman and designers moved into

85.82.text:
the workshops almost all the parts were
manufactured using sketches assembly

90.80.text:
wasn't so much according to the
documents as according to on-the-spot

94.37.text:
fitting". The satellite designed by
korolyov's council of chief designers

99.35.text:
contained a radio transmission system
that looked very similar to Sputnik one

103.25.text:
above it was placed an instrument to
study cosmic radiation and below was the

108.35.text:
cabin that would hold the dog. That
technology already existed because the

112.73.text:
Soviets have been sending up and
other into the atmosphere since

116.30.text:
1951 although those experiments had only
involved flights of one or two hours. The

122.42.text:
Sputnik cabin was modified and included
an air-supply gelatin food

127.43.text:
water supply there was also a light and
a 100 line TV camera so scientists on

133.16.text:
the ground could watch their progress
About 10 days before the flight military

138.50.text:
physician vladimir zovsky selected Laiker
to fly on Sputnik to the name Laiker

144.86.text:
means barker and was the female mongrels
second name after first being called

150.08.text:
Kudryavka or "little curly". Laiker and
the others were strays picked up

155.81.text:
from the streets of moscow and believed
to be the best candidates because

159.50.text:
they've learned to endure the extreme
cold and hunger. Laiker weighed six

164.54.text: kilograms and have been selected because she appeared to be the best behaved

168.11.text:
amongst the ten candidates a dog called
Albina was selected as a backup whilst a

173.27.text:
third dog mukha was used to test
equipment on the ground. Sputnik 2 lifted

178.58.text:
off on November 3rd in 1957 just after
5:30 p.m. Moscow time and entered the

184.55.text:
low Earth orbit 297 seconds later. It
took just over 103 minutes to circle the

191.00.text:
planet were the nearest distance of 211
kilometres 131 miles and the farthest

196.85.text:
distance of 1659 kilometers or 1031
miles. Sputnik 2 had no way to return to

204.62.text:
Earth so it was only ever going to be a
one-way trip for Laiker. the batteries

209.33.text:
providing life-support were thought to
be good for just 6 days meaning that

213.59.text:
She would fail long before the end of a
flight it was later revealed that she

218.21.text:
gone much earlier and probably due to
overheating of her cabin. During the

222.83.text:
first three orbits her vital signs
appeared normal

226.01.text:
although she had been agitated during
the launch procedure by the fourth orbit

230.42.text:
less than seven hours into the mission
the temperature had risen to 43 degrees

234.89.text:
Celsius or 109 Fahrenheit and by
November 4th the only life sign was

239.54.text:
a heartbeat. By the third day of the
mission no life signs were reported.

245.06.text:
Boris Chertok later admitted that
everyone knew the flight was a death

248.87.text:
sentence for Laiker. he said "That it was
virtually impossible to create a

253.16.text:
reliable life-support and thermal
control system within such a short

257.51.text:
period of time it was a complete triumph
none of us doubted that the Americans

262.46.text:
had been put to shame only the British
Royal Society for Prevention of cruelty

267.29.text: animals protested laikers martyrdom " Some scientist had planned on euthanizing

273.56.text:
Laiker by poisoning her food so she
wouldn't go in panic from the

277.43.text:
overheating but it seems that this was
not done in 1998.  Oleg Gazenko the

283.91.text:
scientist that selected and trained like
her expressed his regret for her end

287.96.text:
and said to following "Work with animals
is a source of suffering to all of us we

293.39.text:
treat them like babies who cannot speak
the more time that passes the more I am

298.31.text:
sorry about it we shouldn't have done it
we didn't learn enough from a mission to

303.47.text:
justify the end of the dog"
Sputnik 2's orbit decayed on April 14th

308.90.text:
1958 after completing 2570 orbits of
Earth with the debris including Laikers

315.32.text:
remains impacting the Amazon region in
South America. By that time Sputnik 1 was

320.24.text:
long gone and the USA have placed their
first satellite Explorer 1 into orbit

325.04.text:
with a flight that was to last 12 years.
Laiker it wasn't the first creature in space

330.50.text:
but she was the first creature to orbit
Earth On February 20th 1947 the USA had

337.73.text:
sent up fruit flies aboard a captured
German v2 rocket in an early experiment

342.65.text:
into how radiation affects living beings.
Two monkeys called Albert had been

348.05.text:
launched later Albert one failed during
the V2 flight of June 11th 1948 now but

353.54.text: two failed on impact when his V2 returned back to earth. On June 25th 1949 then on

360.68.text:
December 12th Albert 4 suffered no ill
effects during the flight but failed on

366.35.text: impact after the parachute failed. It wasn't

369.32.text: until September 2 20th 1951 but a monkey called Yorick an 11 mice came back OK

376.73.text:
from an American missile flight. In July
22nd 1951 the USSR launched two dogs

383.45.text:
Tsygan and Dezik into space although
they weren't the first creatures to enter

388.34.text:
orbit they were the first creatures
to be safely landed after the flight. On

392.75.text:
May 28 1959 two monkeys miss Abel a
rhesus monkey and miss Baker a squirrel

399.95.text:
monkey became the first two creatures to
be launched 300 miles or 480 kilometers

405.44.text:
into space by a Jupiter rocket and to be
recovered at alive by the United States.

411.37.text:
Although they survived acceleration
forces of 38G and 16 minutes in space

417.98.text:
miss Abel passed way four days after from an
adverse reaction to an anaesthetic

424.07.text:
during an operation to remove electrodes
used in the flight. Miss Baker went on to

429.56.text: become quite famous at the US Space and Rocket Center entertaining visitors to

434.21.text:
the museum and receiving hundreds of
letters a day from schoolchildren. Miss

438.83.text:
Baker lived until November 29th 1984
becoming the oldest living squirrel

444.80.text:
monkey at the age of 27.
After Laiker the USSR sent up two more

450.32.text:
dogs Belka and Strelka on August 4 1919
60 along with a grey rabbit 42 mice two

457.94.text:
rats
15 flasks of fruit flies and some plants.

461.06.text:
This was the first mission to place
creatures into orbit and bring them back

465.62.text:
alive. On january 31st 1961 a trained
chimpanzee called ham operated levers on

472.88.text:
a project mercury mission becoming the
first animal to interact with flight

477.02.text:
controls having proved that it was
possible to operate a machine in space

481.61.text:
without the dangerous delays caused by
the environment ham paved the way for

486.11.text:
Alan Shepard to become the first
American in space aboard freedom 7 on

491.24.text: May 2 5th 1961. Enos the chimp became the 3rd hominid after Yuri Gagarin and

497.48.text:
Gherman Titov to orbit the Earth in
November 1961 in what was to become a

502.88.text:
full dress rehearsal for John Glenn's
first orbital mission in February 1962.

508.25.text:
In the same way the Soviet animals
had enabled Yuri Gagarin  to

513.17.text:
become the first human in space,
Gagarin himself jokingly referred to it

517.82.text:
by saying "I don't know whether I am the
first man in space or the last dog in

527.24.text:
tortoises, some worms and flies became
the first living creatures to orbit the

532.34.text:
moon and return safely back to earth
aboard the Soviet Zond 5. Since then the

539.60.text: kinds of creatures have been sent into space has increased as has a number of nations

543.50.text:
sending them there the list includes
frogs, rabbits, guinea pigs, fish, geckos,

548.69.text:
spiders and dozens of other types of
insects. In September 2007 a group of

554.57.text:
tardigrades also known as water bears
eight-legged micro animals known for be

559.85.text:
capable of going into a form of
suspended animation were sent into space

563.45.text:
on the outside of a FOTON-M3 rocket for
10 days upon arrival back on earth 68%

571.73.text:
of them had survived the cold irradiated
vacuum of outer space. The moral question

577.76.text:
of whether we should continue sending
creatures into space or whether we should

581.87.text:
have ever done it in the first place
remains a hot topic some argue that even

587.45.text:
in the early days of space travel the
only living things that should have been

591.62.text:
sent up there were people had made the
conscious decision to go and knew the

596.48.text:
risks. Others point out but whilst it may
have been necessary to do it in the past

600.73.text:
modern flights are nothing more
than sideshows another point of view is

605.99.text:
that as we look forward to long-term
plans to sending humans to Mars and

610.34.text:
beyond we may once again have to rely
upon creatures to take the risk for us. In

616.58.text:
2013 the UK's Guardian newspaper ran a
poll asking the question should we send

622.52.text:
animals into space 21% of responders
said yes while 79% said no the topic has

630.26.text:
received renewed interest when in 2015
University of Miami philosopher Marc

636.38.text:
Rowland's published a book in which he'd
gathered recent evidence to claim that

640.58.text:
animals were capable of understanding
right from wrong and therefore could be

645.47.text:
as moral or even more
than us. So thanks for watching and don't

652.06.text:
forget we also have the curious droid
Facebook page and group the link is in

655.18.text:
the channel page and you can also
translate any other videos with the

658.45.text:
community contributions would also like
to thank all of our patrons for their

662.23.text:
ongoing support and if you would like to
support us then please click on the

665.98.text:
patreon link now showing so as always
thanks again for watching and please
